awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Role of Coupled Chemistry-climate Interactions in Internal Climate Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
A great deal of past research has been directed at understanding how coupling between climate and chemical species such as ozone and water vapor influence the climate response to anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases and ozone-depleting substances. But the importance of such coupling for year-to-year and decadal-scale variations in climate represents a key gap in our current scientific understanding of the climate system.  The project will fill this gap through analyses of both existing numerical experiments across a wide array of climate models, and from new numerical simulations explicitly for the current project. The outcomes of the project will lead to improved understanding of the role of chemistry-climate coupling in the climate system. The work has broad implications for our understanding of climate variability and change, and their related climate impacts at the surface. 

The project will provide new insights into the importance of coupled chemistry-climate interactions for climate variability in the tropics, midlatitudes, and polar regions, and at both troposphere and stratosphere. It will improve our understanding of the importance of including coupled chemistry-climate processes in designing and evaluating future large-ensemble climate simulations. In particular, it will provide a benchmark for quantifying the importance of model-to-model differences in chemistry-climate interactions in simulations of climate change. This would help establish the fidelity of the processes included in global climate models, and thus has implications for public confidence in climate models and understanding of climate science. The new knowledge about the role of coupled chemistry-climate interactions in uncertainty in climate change projections would have a range of potential implications for both society and ecosystems over various regions of the globe. The project will also provide mentoring for two graduate students from groups underrepresented in the atmospheric sciences.    

In the first part of the work, the investigators will quantify the effects of coupled chemistry-climate interactions on climate variability on year-to-year timescales. They will explore in both existing and targeted numerical climate model experiments: 1) the differences in climate variability between control simulations with and without coupled chemistry; 2) the influence of atmospheric dynamics on various chemical species; and 3) the effects of variations in chemical species on atmospheric dynamics. The second part of the work will explore the role of coupled chemistry-climate interactions in climate change as the world moves from the era of ozone depletion when ozone depleting substances increased (about 1980-1995), to ozone recovery (1995-future). The investigators will focus on 1) variability in future climate states, 2) surface climate trends on decadal timescales, and 3) uncertainty in projections of future climate changes in large-ensemble simulations of coupled chemistry-climate models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of coupled chemistry-climate interactions for internal climate variability and in climate change projections is highly uncertain. The goal of the proposed research was to improve our understanding of the role of coupled chemistry climate interactions in climate change. A partial list of outcomes includes the following highlights (overlap with the MIT report is listed where appropriate): 

- We found that coupled chemistry-climate interactions increase the variability of temperature by a factor of ~two in the lower tropical stratosphere and to a lesser extent in the Southern Hemisphere polar stratosphere. The results highlight the fundamental role of two-way feedbacks between the atmospheric circulation and chemistry in driving climate variability in the lower stratosphere.  (Yook et al., J. Climate, 2020). (also in the MIT report)

- We revealed that the climate feedbacks and climate sensitivity in a dynamical core model are determined by its prescribed thermal relaxation time scales. Thus the relationships between the thermal relaxation time scale and the climatological circulation provide insights into the relationships between the thermal relaxation time scale and the circulation response to a global warming–like forcing perturbation. The results provided novel insight into the circulation response to global warming and thermodynamic constraints on the circulation (Davis et al. J. Climate. 2022).

- The latter months of 2020 were marked by one of the largest Antarctic ozone holes on record. That such large ozone holes occurred despite ongoing ozone recovery raises questions about their origins and climate impacts. We provided novel evidence that supports the hypothesis that the ozone holes were influenced by the Australian wildfires of early 2020. We further revealed that the ozone holes were associated with widespread changes in Southern Hemisphere climate that are consistent with the established climate impacts of Antarctic ozone depletion, including a strengthening of the polar stratospheric vortex, enhanced surface westerlies over the Southern Ocean, and surface temperature changes over Antarctica and Australia.  (Yook et al., Geophys. Res. Lett., 2022; Yook thesis). (also in the MIT report)

- We demonstrated that the post–2001 recovery in stratospheric ozone resulted in significant changes in the trends in thermal and circulation features of the SH, with climate changes extending from the stratosphere into the troposphere and surface.  The changes are generally of opposite sign to those that resulted from stratospheric ozone losses, and include warming of the SH polar lower stratosphere and weakening of the SH stratospheric polar vortex, thereby providing novel information on the emergence of dynamical impacts of the healing of the Antarctic ozone hole. (Zambri et al., Nature Communications, 2021) (also in the MIT report)

- The width of the tropics is important for climate change, particularly drying trends at the edges of the tropics; such changes have been shown to extend from the stratosphere to the troposphere.  We probed tropical width in the stratosphere using chemical tracers including nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons, which are accessible by direct measurement.  We demonstrated that unlike previously proposed stratospheric width methods, the tracer metrics perform consistently throughout the depth of the stratosphere, at all times of year, and on coarse temporal data. We also examined the effects of oscillations within the stratosphere (the quasi-biennial oscillation) on the distributions of these tracers in the troposphere and stratosphere (Shah et al, 2020, 2022). (also in the MIT report)
